header.title: The Scroll of Set, Issue Number 88

central_thesis: This issue of The Scroll of Set explores various facets of Setian philosophy and magical practice, emphasizing individual self-transformation (Xeper), the conscious creation of immortality through a 'magical self,' esoteric interpretations of historical symbols like Baphomet, and the application of Setian principles to literature and direct magical experience, all within a framework of radical self-responsibility and challenge to conventional thought.

structure_content.chapter_title: [1] The Return of the Son of Hamlet
structure_content.summary: This article introduces the theory of 'dual consciousness,' positing that beyond physical death, a 'magical self' can be actively created and nurtured through ritual and subjective universe access. This magical self, a product of individual effort rather than inherent endowment, is proposed as a vehicle for consciousness capable of achieving immortality, in contrast to passive, faith-based approaches. It emphasizes the Setian perspective of self-created existence.

structure_content.chapter_title: [2] Another Theory on the Origin of 'Baphomet'
structure_content.summary: This piece offers a deep historical and esoteric analysis of 'Baphomet,' linking it to the Knights Templar. It describes the Templar idol as a dualistic symbol and highlights the 'talking head' motif. Drawing on Count von Hardenberg's 1931 work, it interprets a specific magical square (SATAN/ADAMA/TABAT/AMADA/NATAS) to derive 'Baphomet' as a Latin phrase, 'B A fomitem habemus' ('from the letters B and A we have the igniter of fire'), connecting it to primal creative fire and the Templars' official name, positioning the Order within the tradition of Black Magic.

A short, atmospheric poem evoking a sense of disquieting encounter or internal transformation, using imagery of a 'corsair,' 'amber-scented, windless night,' and the lasting impact of 'talons' wounds,' suggesting a profound, unsettling magical experience.

structure_content.chapter_title: [4] Book Review: The Greater Trumps by Charles Williams
structure_content.summary: This review commends Charles Williams' novel for exploring the Tarot as an active tool of 'kinetic magic.' It suggests that while the book's methods are described as 'heavy-handed' and 'dangerous,' it offers valuable insights for adventurous practitioners interested in practical magical experimentation, and highlights the interpretive flexibility of Tarot correspondences for initiates.

A poetic tribute to H.P. Lovecraft, praising his ability to envision and articulate 'worlds horrifying compared to the civilized modern, yet exhilarating and exciting.' It characterizes Lovecraft as an 'Opulent entrepreneur of fear and horror,' who, through his work, rides 'on the wings of the Ancient Ones.'

structure_content.chapter_title: [6] Book Review: Stranger in a Strange Land by Robert Heinlein
structure_content.summary: This highly commendatory review presents Heinlein's novel as a 'Satanic statement' and a guide for Setian Xeper. It emphasizes the protagonist, Michael Smith, as a model for 'godlike' existence through self-knowledge, the ability to 'grok' (deeply understand essence), and an ethics of personal responsibility. The review interprets 'Thou art God' as an 'unafraid, unabashed assumption of personal responsibility,' highlighting the novel's call for individual evolution and self-deification, contrasting it with externalized religious concepts.

This editorial discusses the birth of children within Setian families, coining the term 'second-generation Setians.' It observes the notable individuality and brilliance of these children, attributing their development to their 'magical environment and education.' The piece suggests that being raised within Setian philosophy fosters unique and strong individuals, implying a significant future for them.

A personal account of a mystical experience during 'misagi breathing,' where the author encountered a joyous, horned apparition in a subjective space. This 'Laughing God' conveyed the imperative to 'Xeper or die,' advised against mundane distractions, and affirmed the existence of others who receive the 'Gift of Set.' The experience significantly increased the author's energy and reinforced the importance of Xeper and the 'cosmic joy of life.'

A dense, poetic piece exploring themes of creation and decay, depicting the origins of humanity from a 'Creatrix or creator masturbating' and the subsequent struggle amidst 'wreckage.' It uses stark, sometimes grotesque imagery to convey a primal, raw, and perhaps cynical view of existence, touching on human ambition, conflict, and the inevitability of destruction.

A declarative statement of Luciferian/Satanic philosophy, rejecting conventional virtues like altruism, pacifism, 'justice,' and the 'normal' societal standards. It asserts the voice of the 'admittedly selfish,' pursuing the 'flame of Life,' vengeance, logic, pleasure, and creativity. The piece culminates in the bold declaration, 'Mine is the voice of Satan, who delights in great evil,' outlining an anti-conventional and intensely individualistic ethos.

A poetic invocation dedicated to Lilith, also identified as Hecate, the 'Queen of Hell.' The goddess is portrayed as a guiding light for the practitioner ('wandering beast') and a source of 'infinite and eternal joy and rapture' for Dæmons. The text speaks of polluting 'sacred vessels of man' and offering 'fruit from the tree of knowledge of good and evil,' empowering individuals to choose their own path to profound joy.

key_concepts.definition: A theoretical model positing the existence of both an objective consciousness (tied to the physical world) and a subjective consciousness (operating in a subjective universe). The latter can be cultivated into a 'magical self' for potential post-mortem survival.

An independent vehicle for consciousness, actively created, nurtured, and strengthened through ritual and self-reflection, intended to outlive the objective consciousness and achieve personal immortality.

A core Setian concept meaning 'To Come Into Being' or 'Self-Becoming.' It denotes an active, conscious process of self-transformation, evolution, and deification, transcending one's current state and societal limitations.

An esoteric symbol traditionally associated with the Knights Templar, interpreted as a dualistic representation of integrated opposites. In this context, it is derived from a magical square and linked to the Latin phrase 'B A fomitem habemus' ('from the letters B and A we have the igniter of fire'), symbolizing primal creative energy and connection to the Templar Order's secret identity.

From Robert Heinlein's 'Stranger in a Strange Land,' adopted by Setians to mean 'to drink' in the sense of profound, essential understanding, becoming identified with the very essence of something, beyond mere intellectual or physical contact. It represents deep, intuitive comprehension.

A specific manifestation encountered during ritual, depicted as a joyous, horned figure. This entity communicates the imperative of Xeper, warns against mundane distractions, and affirms that the 'Gift of Set' is not exclusive to the practitioner, signifying confidence and cosmic joy in self-becoming.

The unique insight, potential, or inherent drive within certain individuals that enables them to pursue Xeper and a path of self-deification, distinguishing them from those who rely on externalized religious or societal constructs.

A term used within the Setian context to refer to magical practices and philosophies that challenge conventional morality and spiritual norms. It emphasizes individual power, self-transformation, and the pursuit of knowledge and experience beyond traditional constraints, often with Luciferian or Satanic undertones, as exemplified by the Templars' esoteric practices.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined or implied in this issue is centered on the active, conscious development of the 'magical self' and the relentless pursuit of Xeper (Self-Becoming). It mandates internal transformation, challenging limiting beliefs, and engaging with subjective realities through ritual. This path aims for individual responsibility, self-deification, and the creation of personal immortality, distinct from passively received spiritual benefits. It's an operative system focused on the magician's direct intervention in their own evolution and consciousness.
tools: Objective consciousness, utilized as an 'alchemist's oven' for critical analysis, distillation, and enhancement of subjective experiences.
Tarot, employed as an active tool for 'kinetic magic' and the exploration of energetic principles.
Conceptual logic and deep understanding of one's own nature, derived from principles like 'grokking,' to facilitate self-knowledge and effective action.
rituals: Altering consciousness during ritual to access and work within subjective universes.
Misagi breathing (a martial arts technique) to induce altered states of consciousness for apparitional encounters and deeper insights.
General 'ritual' and 'magical practice' for the creation, nurturing, and strengthening of the 'magical self.'

relevant_quotes.text: immortality - it is created, not given or found. It is not a circumstance of the universe, but a product of the individual.

I would now propose a distinction be made: that the perspective I use in the subjective universe is not the objective perspective in fancy clothes. It is a facet of myself created by my objective perspective.
B A fomitem habemus: 'from the letters B and A we have the igniter of fire'
I've found out why people laugh. They laugh because it hurts because it's the only thing that'll make it stop hurting.
Thou art God. It's not a message of cheer and hope, Jubal. It's a defiance and an unafraid, unabashed assumption of personal responsibility.
Mine is the voice of Satan, who delights in great evil.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue of The Scroll of Set is highly relevant for understanding the core tenets and ongoing development of Setian philosophy and magical practice. It provides detailed theoretical frameworks for immortality and consciousness, esoteric historical interpretations (Baphomet), and practical insights into personal magical experiences and self-transformation (Xeper). The articles collectively reinforce the Setian emphasis on radical individualism, self-deification, and a distinct Left-Hand Path approach to spirituality, directly contrasting with conventional religious and occult paradigms.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of initiated members of the Temple of Set, evidenced by the use of specialized terminology, references to internal publications, and the assumption of familiarity with Setian concepts like Xeper. A secondary audience includes academics and practitioners in Western Esotericism and occult studies who seek to understand contemporary Left-Hand Path movements and their engagement with historical and philosophical magical traditions.
